channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Suspects in China Market Attack Identified
item.description: Four of the men were killed when the two vehicles they used to mount the attack exploded in Urumqi, the regional capital.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Observers Go to Ukraine for Election Separatists Plan to Disrupt
item.description: An official from the unrecognized Donetsk People’s Republic said that his group had confiscated official voting center stamps and some ballots.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Tempting Europe With Ugly Fruit
item.description: Isabel Soares has bet that there is a market for fruits and vegetables deemed too ugly by government bureaucrats, supermarkets and other retailers to sell to their consumers.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A volunteer with Fruta Feia, or Ugly Fruit, with a strawberry deemed too deformed by European officials to sell in ordinary food outlets.

item.title: Militants Attack Somalia’s Parliament
item.description: Witnesses and officials reported a bomber detonating a car filled with explosives at the Parliament building’s entrance, followed by several explosions and an assault by gunmen.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: A Somali soldier ran toward Parliament as others took cover in Mogadishu on Saturday.

item.title: In Possible Thaw, Pakistani Leader Agrees to Attend Modi’s Swearing-In Ceremony
item.description: The invitation by Narendra Modi, India’s new prime minister, indicated a possible upturn in relations between the two longtime rivals.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: India’s new prime minister, Narendra Modi, arriving at the parliament building in New Delhi on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Separatist Rebels in Mali Agree to a Truce
item.description: Tuareg separatist groups in Mali on Friday accepted a cease-fire agreement with the government after clashes this week that threatened to plunged the country back into war.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: 6 Gunned Down on Bus in El Salvador
item.description: Gunmen boarded a bus in a town near San Salvador, the Salvadoran capital, opened fired on passengers, killing six, including three law enforcement officials, the police said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: 2 Killed in Political Violence in Egypt
item.description: Two protesters were killed in clashes in Egypt between Islamist demonstrators and their opponents after midday prayers on Friday, the final day of campaigning ahead of next week’s presidential election, the authorities said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Turkey Says 2 Have Died After a Protest in Istanbul
item.description: One bystander and one protester died of injuries sustained during clashes at a demonstration against last week’s mine disaster in Soma, Istanbul’s governor said.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: World Briefing: Gunmen Attack Consulate in Afghanistan
item.description: Gunmen armed with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades attacked the Indian Consulate in the western Afghan city of Herat on Friday, but its diplomatic staff members escaped unharmed, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Anti-China Protester Dies in Vietnam
item.description: A Vietnamese woman set herself on fire in downtown Ho Chi Minh City to protest China’s positioning of an oil rig in waters claimed by Vietnam, the state news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ‘Happy in Tehran’ Video Spurs Harsher Censorship
item.description: The judicial authorities in Iran moved to block Instagram and imprisoned the director who made the now-famous Iranian version of the Pharrell Williams “Happy” video.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Europe’s Right and Left on March to Populism
item.description: With voting for the European Parliament concluding on Sunday, the elections will provide the best indicator yet of the depth of disillusionment and anger in southern Europe — and whether it will give rise to new political powers.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Mario Carlin/Iguana Press, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Beppe Grillo, a former comedian and actor who now leads the Five Star Movement party, performing in Bologna last month.

item.title: Jaime Lusinchi, Ex-Leader of Venezuela, Dies at 89
item.description: Mr. Lusinchi, who was president during economic and political crises from 1984 to 1989, gave his mistress a position of power in his government.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Nigeria’s Army Holding Up Hunt for Taken Girls
item.description: Foreign diplomats say that the Islamist group Boko Haram appears to be winning the struggle with a weak military.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Calm Streets Mask Deep Divisions in Donetsk
item.description: Ukraine’s east is more deeply divided than at any point in the country’s history, and residents say it is possible that Sunday’s presidential election will do little to change that.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Young Ukrainians enjoyed a sunny afternoon this week at a city pond in central Donetsk.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Claim Attack on Assad Supporters
item.description: An Islamist rebel group took responsibility for attacking a tent erected as part of the coming presidential election. More than 20 people died.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Ukraine Faces Struggle to Gain Control of Militias, Including Those on Its Side
item.description: A battle on Friday showed the devastating potential for violence between ad hoc militias, which could continue even if Ukraine’s army ceases its military campaign against the rebel groups.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian militiamen rested on Friday near the body of a member of the pro-Ukrainian Donbass Battalion at a checkpoint about 10 miles west of Donetsk.

item.title: U.S. Gains in a Spat With China Over Tariffs
item.description: The ruling by the World Trade Organization gives the Obama administration another opportunity to portray itself as being willing to confront Beijing on trade issues.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A Jeep billboard in Shanghai. China has emerged as a large market in terms of vehicles sales.

item.title: Thai Military Detains Ousted Leaders as Coup Sets Off Small Acts of Protest
item.description: Leading members of Thailand’s largest political party surrendered themselves to the military on Friday, a day after the head of the army overthrew the country’s elected government.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Thai police and army soldiers stood guard outside a military compound before former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra arrived on Friday.

item.title: Open Source: Anger at Killing of Bystander During Protest in Turkey
item.description: One day after a bystander was shot and killed near a protest in Istanbul, there was criticism of the pace of the investigation into his death.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Mourners in Istanbul on Friday carried the coffin of Ugur Kurt, a bystander who was killed during clashes between protesters and the police the day before.

item.title: Britain’s Discontent Lifts Populist Party to Even Stronger Vote Tally Than Expected
item.description: The United Kingdom Independence Party seemed to confirm its role as an emerging political force after early results indicated a strong showing in local elections.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Nigel Farage spoke to reporters near Biggin Hill, England, on Friday. His U.K. Independence Party has campaigned for controls on immigration and for a British exit from the European Union.

item.title: Iran Is Providing Information on Its Detonators, Atomic Agency Says
item.description: The disclosure that a substantive discussion on nuclear detonators had begun with the agency suggested a significant change in tactics in Tehran.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Desperate Mother’s Search Leads to a Fight Against Sex Trafficking
item.description: Desperate for answers about her daughter’s disappearance in 2002, Susana Trimarco started the Fundación María de los Ángeles, an organization that rescues and rehabilitates sex slaves in Argentina.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Susana Trimarco holding a photo of her daughter at a Mass in 2008, a year after she founded the Fundación María de los Ángeles to combat sex trafficking.

item.title: World Briefing: King Richard III to Be Reburied in Leicester, British Court Says
item.description: The court ruled that the king, who died in 1485, should be reburied in a cathedral in Leicester,​ the city​ where his remains were found in a parking lot in 2012, and not in York.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: University of Leicester/University of Leicester, via Associated Press
item.media:description: King Richard III of England, who died in 1485, was missing for 500 years. A British court ruled that he will be buried in a cathedral in Leicester.
